what is a pestle? If I don't have one can I use something else?
That's a really good question! Let me see what I can find

Mortar and pestle are implements used since ancient times to prepare ingredients or substances by crushing and grinding them into a fine paste or powder in the kitchen, laboratory, and pharmacy. The "mortar"  is a bowl, typically made of hard wood, metal, ceramic, or hard stone, such as granite. The "pestle"  is a heavy and blunt club-shaped object.

provenance.page_title: Mortar and pestle
provenance.paragraph_text: Mortar and pestle are implements used since ancient times to prepare ingredients or substances by crushing and grinding them into a fine paste or powder in the kitchen, laboratory, and pharmacy. The "mortar" () is a bowl, typically made of hard wood, metal, ceramic, or hard stone, such as granite. The "pestle" (, ) is a heavy and blunt club-shaped object. The substance to be ground, which may be wet or dry, is placed in the mortar, where the pestle is pressed and rotated onto it until the desired texture is achieved.

Yes you can use pink salt.  Himalayan Pink Salt is basically table salt with some added chemicals. It is merely dyed pink to help it blend better 

However, Himalayan Pink Salt is not processed like table salt. Himalayan contains additional trace minerals.

provenance.page_title: Is Himalayan pink salt the same as the pink salt used for curing?
provenance.paragraph_text:
I have been using Himalayan Pink Salt for years...it is the only salt I use. 

Curing salt is basically table salt with some added chemicals. It is merely dyed pink to help it blend better with meat.

Himalayan Pink Salt is not processed like table salt. Himalayan contains additional trace minerals. 

Salt with trace minerals always has a non-white color. Celtic Sea Salt, for example (which is really good salt) has a brownish sandy color. Pink Himalayan salt is a sort of sandy rose or pink color. All the truly natural full-spectrum salts are sandy, pink, or brownish in color.

conversation.utterance: Thank you for telling me that, I had no idea that it had dye in it!

You need basil. Unless you're from Liguria itself, you probably don't have access to the prized basil of that region. If you happen to grow your own, lucky you. If you have access to a good farmers market that carries beautiful tufts of fragrant basil at the height of summer, definitely go for it. If you have to settle for supermarket clamshells of hydroponic herb, well, then, that's what it's going to be. Basically, get the best fresh basil you can, and that's all there is to it.

provenance.paragraph_text: What Cheese Should Be Used in Pesto Sauce?

conversation.utterance: Historically, the cheeses of true Ligurian pesto were Parmigiano-Reggiano and Pecorino Sardo (or Fiore Sardo), a Sardinian sheep's-milk cheese.

provenance.page_title: How to Make the Best Pesto
provenance.section_title: What Cheese Should Be Used in Pesto Sauce?
provenance.paragraph_text: Historically, the cheeses of true Ligurian pesto were Parmigiano-Reggiano and Pecorino Sardo (or Fiore Sardo), a Sardinian sheep's-milk cheese.

conversation.utterance: When pesto first became popular in the United States, however, Fiore Sardo was pretty much unavailable here, so recipe writers substituted the next best available thing: Pecorino Romano.

conversation.utterance: Perfect
also can you tell me more about when Pesto was invented?
That's an amazing question! Let me see what I can find!
I would love to see a short video on the history of Pesto if you have one.

Pesto or to refer to the original dish pesto alla genovese , is a sauce originating in Genoa, the capital city of Liguria, Italy.  Pesto is thought to have two predecessors in ancient times, going back as far as the Roman age. The ancient Romans used to eat a similar paste called moretum, which was made by crushing garlic, salt, cheese, herbs, olive oil and vinegar together. The use of this paste in the Roman cuisine is mentioned in the "Appendix Vergiliana", an ancient collection of poems where the author dwells on the details about the preparation of "moretum". During the Middle Ages, a popular sauce in the Genoan cuisine was "agliata", which was basically a mash of garlic and walnuts, as garlic was a staple in the nutrition of Ligurians, especially for the seafarers. The introduction of basil, the main ingredient of modern pesto, occurred in more recent times and is first documented only in the mid-19th century, when gastronomist Giovanni Battista Ratto published his book "La Cuciniera Genovese" in 1863:

provenance.page_title: Pesto
provenance.paragraph_text: Pesto (, ), or to refer to the original dish pesto alla genovese (), is a sauce originating in Genoa, the capital city of Liguria, Italy. It traditionally consists of crushed garlic, European pine nuts, coarse salt, basil leaves, hard cheese such as Parmigiano-Reggiano (also known as Parmesan cheese) or Pecorino Sardo (cheese made from sheep's milk), all blended with olive oil.

provenance.page_title: Pesto

The use of this paste in the Roman cuisine is mentioned in the "Appendix Vergiliana", an ancient collection of poems where the author dwells on the details about the preparation of "moretum". During the Middle Ages, a popular sauce in the Genoan cuisine was "agliata", which was basically a mash of garlic and walnuts, as garlic was a staple in the nutrition of Ligurians, especially for the seafarers.

also can you tell me what emulsified means?

An emulsion is a mixture of two or more liquids that are normally immiscible (unmixable or unblendable). Emulsions are part of a more general class of two-phase systems of matter called colloids. Although the terms "colloid" and "emulsion" are sometimes used interchangeably, "emulsion" should be used when both phases, dispersed and continuous, are liquids. In an emulsion, one liquid (the dispersed phase) is dispersed in the other (the continuous phase). Examples of emulsions include vinaigrettes, homogenized milk, and some cutting fluids for metal working.

provenance.page_title: Emulsion
provenance.paragraph_text: An emulsion is a mixture of two or more liquids that are normally immiscible (unmixable or unblendable). Emulsions are part of a more general class of two-phase systems of matter called colloids. Although the terms "colloid" and "emulsion" are sometimes used interchangeably, "emulsion" should be used when both phases, dispersed and continuous, are liquids. In an emulsion, one liquid (the dispersed phase) is dispersed in the other (the continuous phase). Examples of emulsions include vinaigrettes, homogenized milk, and some cutting fluids for metal working.
